title: Matt Tees
text:
Matthew Tees (13 October 1939 – 4 November 2020) was a Scottish <a href="association%20football">footballer</a>.
Originally a <a href="machinist">machinist</a> at a <a href="carpet">carpet</a> factory, he was discovered while playing for local leagues in Scotland with <a href="Cambuslang%20Rangers">Cambuslang Rangers</a>. After a spell with <a href="Airdrieonians%20F.C.%20%281878%29">Airdrie</a>, he played for <a href="Grimsby%20Town">Grimsby Town</a> (two spells), <a href="Charlton%20Athletic%20F.C.">Charlton Athletic</a> and <a href="Luton%20Town">Luton Town</a> before ending his career with <a href="Boston%20United">Boston United</a> in the <a href="Northern%20Premier%20League">Northern Premier League</a>.
He died on 4 November 2020, at the age of 81.
Career.
After beginning his career in the local leagues in Scotland with <a href="Cambuslang%20Rangers">Cambuslang Rangers</a> before joining professional <a href="Association%20football">football</a> with <a href="Airdrieonians%20F.C.%20%281878%29">Airdrie</a>. He then joined <a href="Grimsby%20Town%20F.C.">Grimsby Town</a>, <a href="Charlton%20Athletic%20F.C.">Charlton Athletic</a>, <a href="Luton%20Town%20F.C.">Luton Town</a> and back to <a href="Grimsby%20Town%20F.C.">Grimsby Town</a>, during his second spell at Grimsby, Tees was part of the <a href="1971%E2%80%9372%20in%20English%20football">1971–72</a> team that won the <a href="Football%20League%20Fourth%20Division">Division Four</a> title.
A 2017 <a href="BBC">BBC</a> documentary on <a href="dementia">dementia</a> among retired footballers included a visit to Tees' family home, where it was confirmed he had an advanced stage of the condition; it was suggested that the cause may be the high number of times he headed the ball during his playing career.
